quizzes.question: If we were to replace the break statement in the code with a 'continue', what would happen?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating a Calculator[/h1]

This lesson is about an example Python project: a simple calculator.  
Each part explains a different section of the program. 
The first section is the overall menu. This keeps on accepting user input until the user enters "quit", so a [b]while[/b] loop is used.[code format="py"][b]while [/b]True:
   print("Options:")
   print("Enter 'add' to add two numbers")
   print("Enter 'subtract' to subtract two numbers")
   print("Enter 'multiply' to multiply two numbers")
   print("Enter 'divide' to divide two numbers")
   print("Enter 'quit' to end the program")
   user_input = input(": ")

   [b]if [/b]user_input == "quit":
      [b]break[/b]
   [b]elif [/b]user_input == "add":
      ...
   [b]elif [/b]user_input == "subtract":
      ...
   [b]elif [/b]user_input == "multiply":
      ...
   [b]elif [/b]user_input == "divide":
      ...
   [b]else:[/b]
      print("Unknown input")[/code]
[note]The code above is the starting point for our program. It accepts user input, and compares it to the options in the[b] if/elif [/b]statements.
The [b]break [/b]statement is used to stop the while loop, in case the user inputs "quit".[/note]

quizzes.question: Why are the calls to float necessary in the code?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating a Calculator [/h1]

The next part of the program is getting the numbers the user wants to do something with. 
The code below shows this for the addition section of the calculator. Similar code would have to be written for the other sections. [code format="py" ][b]elif [/b]user_input == "add":
  num1 = float(input("Enter a number: "))
  num2 = float(input("Enter another number: "))[/code]
Now, when the user inputs "add", the program prompts to enter two numbers, and stores them in the corresponding variables.
[note]As it is, this code crashes if the user enters a non-numeric input when prompted to enter a number. We will look at fixing problems like this in a later module.[/note]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating a Calculator[/h1]

The final part of the program processes user input and displays it. 
The code for the addition part is shown here.[code format="py"][b]elif [/b]user_input == "add":
  num1 = float(input("Enter a number: "))
  num2 = float(input("Enter another number: "))
  result = str(num1 + num2)
  print("The answer is " + result)[/code]
We now have a working program that prompts for user input, and then calculates and prints the sum of the input.
[note]Similar code would have to be written for the other branches (for subtraction, multiplication and division).
The output line could be put outside the [b]if[/b] statements to omit repetition of code.[/note]
